keyPhrases.pronunciation: /aɪ siː jɔːr pɔɪnt bʌt/ 아이 시 유어 포인트 벗

example.A: I think we should cut the budget.
example.B: I see your point, but we also need to invest in growth.

relatedPhrases: I understand what you're saying, but...

keyPhrases.pronunciation: /ðæts ə ɡʊd ˈɑːrɡjumənt/ 댓츠 어 굿 아규먼트
keyPhrases.commonMistakes: 한국에서 'argument'를 부정적으로 이해하기 쉬움. 토론에서는 '논거'라는 중립적 의미

example.A: The data shows a clear trend upward.
example.B: That's a good argument. I hadn't considered that.
To summarize, we agree on the goals but differ on the timeline.

keyPhrases.pronunciation: /let miː æd tə ðæt/ 렛 미 애드 투 댓
keyPhrases.context: 상대의 의견에 추가 의견을 더할 때

example.B: Let me add to that—our return rate has also decreased.

keyPhrases.pronunciation: /wiː kæn əˈɡriː ðæt/ 위 캔 어그리 댓

example.B: We can agree that quality is our top priority.

keyPhrases.pronunciation: /ɒn ðə ˈʌðər hænd/ 온 더 아더 핸드
keyPhrases.context: 반대 의견이나 다른 관점을 제시할 때

example.A: Hiring more staff would be expensive.
example.B: On the other hand, it could increase our capacity significantly.

keyPhrases.pronunciation: /ðæts ɪɡˈzæktli wɒt aɪ miːn/ 댓츠 이그잭틀리 왓 아이 민
keyPhrases.context: 상대가 자신의 의견을 정확히 이해했을 때

example.A: So you're saying we need more time?
example.B: That's exactly what I mean. Quality takes time.

keyPhrases.phrase: I'd like to make a point
keyPhrases.meaning: 한 가지 말씀드리고 싶은 게 있어요
keyPhrases.pronunciation: /aɪd laɪk tə meɪk ə pɔɪnt/ 아이드 라이크 투 메이크 어 포인트

example.A: Does anyone have anything to add?
example.B: I'd like to make a point about the budget allocation.

keyPhrases.phrase: Going back to what you said...
keyPhrases.pronunciation: /ˈɡoʊɪŋ bæk tə wɒt juː sed/ 고잉 백 투 왓 유 세드
keyPhrases.koreanTip: 'going back to'를 하나의 덩어리로 빠르게 연결

example.B: Going back to what you said earlier, I agree we need a clear deadline.

keyPhrases.pronunciation: /aɪm nɒt ʃɔːr aɪ əˈɡriː/ 아임 낫 슈어 아이 어그리
keyPhrases.commonMistakes: 'I'm not agree'가 아닌 'I don't agree' 또는 'I'm not sure I agree'가 맞음

example.B: I'm not sure I agree. We might need more testing.

keyPhrases.phrase: Could you clarify what you mean?
keyPhrases.pronunciation: /kʊd juː ˈklærɪfaɪ wɒt juː miːn/ 쿠드 유 클래리파이 왓 유 민

example.A: We need to pivot our strategy.
example.B: Could you clarify what you mean by 'pivot'?

keyPhrases.pronunciation: /ðæt ˈreɪzɪz ə ɡʊd pɔɪnt/ 댓 레이지즈 어 굿 포인트

example.A: Have we considered the legal implications?
example.B: That raises a good point. We should consult our lawyers.

relatedPhrases: You bring up an important issue.

keyPhrases.phrase: Let's look at this from another angle
keyPhrases.pronunciation: /lets lʊk æt ðɪs frʌm əˈnʌðər ˈæŋɡl/ 렛츠 룩 앳 디스 프럼 어나더 앵글

example.B: Let's look at this from another angle—what's the cost of NOT doing it?

keyPhrases.context: 다른 사람의 입장을 고려해 말할 때

example.B: To be fair, they didn't have much time to prepare.

keyPhrases.phrase: I think we're all on the same page
keyPhrases.meaning: 우리 모두 같은 생각인 것 같아요
keyPhrases.pronunciation: /aɪ θɪŋk wɪr ɔːl ɒn ðə seɪm peɪdʒ/ 아이 씽크 위어 올 온 더 세임 페이지
keyPhrases.koreanTip: 'on the same page'는 관용구. '같은 페이지에 있다'→ '같은 생각이다'
keyPhrases.commonMistakes: 직역하면 어색함. '같은 생각'이라는 의미의 관용구로 이해

example.A: So we all support the new direction?
example.B: I think we're all on the same page here.
